title: 111_s3405
content: The "Close Big Oil Tax Loopholes Act" limits deductions for intangible drilling and development costs and tertiary injectants in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment applies to applicable large taxpayers starting after December 31, 2010. SEC. 3 amends Section 193 of the Internal Revenue Code to limit deductions for tertiary injectants for applicable large taxpayers with gross revenues exceeding $100,000,000. The amendment applies to expenses incurred after December 31, 2010. SEC. 5 amends section 469(c) of the Internal Revenue Code to limit percentage depletion allowance for oil and gas wells for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010. SEC. 5 limits the percentage depletion allowance for oil and gas wells for applicable large taxpayers to zero. This amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2010. SEC. 7 expands the 7-year amortization of geological and geophysical expenditures to applicable large taxpayers starting after December 31, 2010. SEC. 8 amends the Internal Revenue Code to include applicable large taxpayers in the tax on crude oil and natural gas produced from the Outer Continental Shelf in the Gulf of Mexico, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010. "Chapter 56 imposes tax on crude oil and natural gas from the Outer Continental Shelf in the Gulf of Mexico. It includes rules for taxable oil/gas and removal price, along with special definitions." The tax imposed under Chapter 56 is 13 percent of the removal price of taxable crude oil or natural gas. A credit is allowed for Federal royalties paid, limited to the amount of tax imposed. The producer is responsible for paying the tax. "Taxable crude oil or natural gas is subject to a 13 percent tax based on the removal price. A credit for Federal royalties paid is allowed, up to the amount of tax imposed. The producer is responsible for paying the tax." For tax purposes, "taxable crude oil or natural gas" refers to oil or gas produced from Federal submerged lands in the Gulf of Mexico under a lease with the United States. The "removal price" is the selling price per barrel of oil or per 1,000 cubic feet of gas, except in related party sales where a minimum price applies. The removal price for oil or gas between related parties must not be lower than the constructive sales price for determining gross income under section 613. If crude oil or natural gas is removed before sale, the removal price is the constructive sales price. If refining begins on the property before removal, the oil is considered removed when the refining starts, and the removal price is the constructive sales price for income determination. The term 'property' for income determination is defined by section 614. SEC. 5898. SPECIAL RULES AND DEFINITIONS. The Secretary shall oversee tax withholding and deposit for the tax imposed under section 5896 on a quarterly basis. Taxpayers must maintain records, submit returns, and provide information as required by regulations. Each calendar year is considered a taxable period unless specified otherwise by the Secretary. The filing of tax returns will be determined by the Secretary. The tax imposed under section 5896 requires filing of returns, with definitions provided for terms like 'producer', 'crude oil', and 'premises'. The Secretary can adjust removal prices of oil or natural gas to reflect fair market value. The Secretary can adjust removal prices of oil or natural gas to reflect fair market value, and regulations may be prescribed as necessary. Deductibility of tax for severance of crude oil or natural gas from the outer Continental Shelf in the Gulf of Mexico is addressed in the Internal Revenue Code. Chapter 56 imposes a tax on crude oil and natural gas extracted from the Gulf of Mexico's outer Continental Shelf. The amendments apply to oil or gas removed after the Act's enactment date. Additionally, Section 9 modifies foreign tax credit rules for large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. Section 901 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include special rules for large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. Any amount paid to a foreign country or possession of the United States by such companies will not be considered a tax under certain conditions. The amended Section 901 of the Internal Revenue Code introduces special rules for dual capacity taxpayers, specifically large integrated oil companies. Any excess amount paid to a foreign country or possession will not be considered a tax, as long as it exceeds the generally applicable income tax imposed by that country or possession. The term 'dual capacity taxpayer' is defined within this subsection. The term 'dual capacity taxpayer' refers to a person subject to a levy of a foreign country or possession who receives a specific economic benefit from that country. Generally applicable income tax is defined as an income tax imposed on income derived from conducting a trade or business within a foreign country or possession. The term 'large integrated oil company' is defined as an integrated oil company with gross receipts exceeding $1,000,000,000 and an average daily worldwide production of at least 500,000 barrels of crude oil. The amendments made by this section apply to taxes paid or accrued in taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act, except where contrary to any treaty obligation of the United States.
